name: Mesmer
description:
FLAVOR:

  • Greatest hits of metaphysics and superstitions

  • Some of them are real and you don't know why

  • Mark-based (anonymity), ties to aristocracy

WEAPONS:

  • none

ENGAGEMENT:

  • none

ABILITIES:

  • Masks come with a set of abilities

  • Commedia del'Arte / Venetian carnival characters

  • Coming at magic in a similar but opposite way from Arcanist (trial and error)

  • Control magic, force of personality

  • Perhaps this turns into necromancy or summoning ghosts later on

OLD NOTES:

  • Ok, so there’s the actual trend/movement of Mesmerism from the 18th century, but I kind of want this to be a mashup of that plus 19th century Fox sisters spiritualism, plus 15th century European carnaval (“Quinquagesima” in church parlance, which is a great word), with an emphasis on masks and hidden identity.

  • So like a real greatest-hits of metaphysics and superstitions, but specifically catering to the aristocracy. Like your true identity is a secret and people disguise themselves when they come to you, seeking for you to do spooky stuff to/with them.

  • And I think a key element is that a lot of it is bullshit and you know it’s bullshit, but then some of it is decidedly NOT, and you don’t quite understand it and are maybe a bit afraid of it.

  • Mechanically, I think this is where we dump a lot of traditional D&D control magic (charm person, divination stuff, etc.)

Maybe you acquire different masks with advancements, each of which gives you access to different abilities. Maybe there’s a divination mask, an abjuration mask, etc. But it shouldn’t feel academic like those terms. A mask should have a name (see Venetian carnival mask characters, although this maybe precludes a commedia dell'arte class)
